div.l: In cradle it laye · lyche a propre page
Þis wenche welle egrowe and thykke shee was
With Camuse noose and eyen grey as glasse
Buttokkes right broode and brestes rownde an̄ hye
And Ryght fayre here had shee / I kepe not lye
Eke for hir͗e fadre / thowte þat shee was fayre
HerHerHe was in purpos / to make her his eyre
Booþe of cattayle ⁊and of his messuage
And straunge he made it of hir mariage
¶ His Entente was to bee stowe hir hye
In to some worþye bloode of Auncestrye
For wel egoton goode / most beon despendid
In worthi bloode wher it is descendid
Þer fore he wole his oune bloode honour͗e
Þoughe þᵗat men þer of speke / harome ⁊and loure
¶ Gret sooken hathe this Milner / owte of dowte
Withe whete ⁊and malte / of alle þᵉ sheyre abovte
And namly of a fayre a grete collage
Þat men clepe þe soler halle at Chaumberyng
Þer was þeyre whete / and eke hir malte egrounde
Vppon̄ a day hit happid soo in a stounde
Seke lay þᵉ mauncyple / on̄ a maladye
Men demen wisselye þᵗat he shovlde dye
For soþe this myln̉er stale boþᵉ meele ⁊and corne
An hunderithe tymis more þan̄ he did byfore
For here before he stale but curteyselye
But nowe he was a theff owtrageowselye
For wiche þe wardeyne · chidde ⁊and made fare
But ther by sette þis Milner nowght a tare
He craked booste / and swoore it nas not soo
Þenne were þer yong poure scolers twoo
Þat dwellid in that halle / of wiche I saye
Testyff þey wer͗e / and lousty For to playe
And oonly For þeir͗e myrthe and Reuelrye
Vppon̄ þeyre warden · ryght beselye they crye
¶ Nowe geve vs leve sir but a litill stounde
To goo to thertherthe mylne and see oure corne egrounde
And hardelye þey dourste ley wedde þeyr͗e necke
Þe Miln̉er should not stele hem halfe a pekke
Of corne ne by force no sleyght hem be reve
So atte þe laste þe wardeyne gaff hem leve
Iohon hight þᵗat oon / and Aleyne hyght þᵗat oþ̉er
Of a towne were they borne / þᵗat hyght þᵉ strooþer
Far in þe northe I can not tellyn̄ where
Þis Aleyne makethe al Redy his gere
Vppon̄ an̄ horse þe sacke he caste a noon
For þe gooþe Aleyne þe clerke / and eke Iohan
Wᵗith good swerde / and bockeler by theyre syde
Johanne knew þe waye him neodithe lesse a guyde
¶ And atte þe millene / þe sacke a downe he leyþe
Aleyne spake Firste / al haylle Symkyn̄ in feythe
How faren they they yowr͗e dovter ⁊and yowr͗e wyff
Aleyne wel com qduod symkyn by my lyffe
And Iohan alsoo howe nowe / what doo ye her͗e
By god quod Iohan to symkyn̄ / nede naþᵉ noo per͗e
Hym by hovethe serve himselff þᵗat naþe noo swayne
Or ellꝭes he is a foole as clerkis sayn̄
Oure mancyple I hope þᵗat he wolle bee dede
Swa werkꝭes ay þe wanges in his hede
And þer fore am I cōmmen / eke ⁊and Aleyne
To grynde oure corne / and carye hit home A gayne
Spede vs I pray yowe / als soone as yee may
Hit shall bee doon quod Symkyn̄ by þⁱˢ day
¶ What wolle ye doon / whyles corne is in hande
By god by þᵉ hoꝑper ryght þᵉʳ welle I stonde
Quod Iohan to see / howe þᵉ corn ganges Inne
Yette sawe I never be my fader kynne
Howe þᵉ hopper wagges til ⁊and fra
Alayne answerid ⁊and answerid ⁊and saide Iohan wilttowe swa
Þanne wolle I byde be nethe her͗e wᵗith my corne
To see howe þe meele is in Eborne
In til þe trowhe þat shalle bee my disporte
Quod Iohan In feythe / I may bee of yowre sorte
I am als euil a myller as er yee
¶ Þis mylner smeylid of theyre neycetee
And thowte al nys not / but for a wyle
Þey wene no man can hem booþe be gyle
But by my thryffte yette shalle I bler͗e þeir͗e eye
For alle theyre sleythe / in their philosophie
Þe moore qveynte crookꝭes þat þey make
Þe more corne wolle I stele / whan þᵗat I take
¶ In stede of flour͗e þey shull have all wey branne
The gretteste clerke is nowte wiseste man
As whilom the wolphe / speke on to þᵉ mare
Off al theyr͗e arte counte I nowght a tare
Oute of þe dorre he gooþe ful pryuelye
When þᵗat he sawe his tyme / and sofftylye
He lokeþe vppe and downe / til he hath founde
Þe Clerkꝭes hors / þer as he stood ebounde
Be hynde þe mylne / vnder a leeffcyle
And to þᵉ horse he gooþe hym fayre ⁊and wele
He strypethe of þe brydell Ryght a noon
So whanne þe horse was loose / he gynneþe to gon
To ward þe mareyse where wylde marys ranne
Wᵗith we hee trout thorowhe thykke ⁊and thynne
¶ The mylner gooþe a gayne / no word he saide
But doþe his note and wᵗith þe clerkꝭes playde
Til þat theyre corne / was feyre ⁊and wel egrounde
And whan þe mele is sacked and ebounde
Þis Iohan gooþe owte ⁊and fyndeþᵉ þᵉ horse aweye
¶ And ganne ganne to crye harowe ⁊and welaweye
